tn.ref: Who is this who comes from Edom ... Bozrah
tn.text: Isaiah speaks as a watchman using the question and answer format to present this information about Yahweh's judgment on Edom, an enemy of Israel. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "I, Yahweh, am coming from Edom, clothed in red from Bozrah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is the capital city of Edom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "I" refers to Yahweh.

tn.ref: Why are your clothes red, and why ... winepress?
tn.text: This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "The red on your clothing looks makes you look like you have been treading on grapes in a winepress." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
A winepress is a low place carved out of rock in the ground where workers step on the grapes to crush them with their feet, in order to remove the grape juice.
Here "I" refers to Yahweh. This imagery refers to Yahweh destroying his enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: For I looked forward to the day of vengeance
tn.text: Here "day" refers to a period of time. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Yahweh will punish in an appropriate way to bring about justice. His kind of vengeance differs from man's vengence.
Here "year" refers to a specific time appointed by Yahweh for restoring Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Yahweh continues speaking.
Here "arm" represents power. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: and made them drunk in my wrath
tn.text: This means Yahweh made them stunned and senseless by his full wrath and punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "blood" represents the life of Yahweh's enemies that was gushing out so they would die. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "I" refers to Isaiah.
Here "us" refers to Isaiah and the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
"Through all our suffering." Here "their" refers to the people of Israel. Isaiah included himself as a member of the people.
Here "he" refers to Yahweh.
This is a representative who is sent from God's presence.

tn.ref: he lifted them up and carried them
tn.text: This refers to when God protected and saved the people of Israel from the Egyptians many years earlier. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"but we rebelled." Here "they" refers to the people of Israel. Isaiah included himself as a member of the people.
"Yahweh's Holy Spirit"
"we said." Here "they" refers to the people of Israel. Isaiah included himself as a member of the people.

tn.ref: who brought them up out of the sea
tn.text: The story of Yahweh miraculously splitting the waters of the Sea of Reeds so that the Israelites could cross and escape the Egyptians is assumed knowledge. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Leaders are sometimes referred to as "shepherds." AT: "the leaders of his people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The people of Israel continue speaking.

tn.ref: who made his glorious power go with the right hand of Moses
tn.text: Here "right hand" represents the power of Yahweh through Moses. This means it was God's power that enabled Moses to divide the water of the Reed Sea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Like a horse running on flat land, they did not stumble
tn.text: This means that the people of Israel were sure-footed as horses in open country on their travels toward Israel from Egypt. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
The people of Israel continue speaking.

tn.ref: As the cattle that go down into the valley ... rest
tn.text: This image pictures cattle going into a valley where there is green grass and water and emphasizes that God led the people of Israel and took care of them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: to make yourself a name of praise
tn.text: Here "name of praise" refers to honor and one's reputation. AT: "to make sure you have an honored reputation for yourself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The people of Israel continue speaking.

tn.ref: Where are your zeal and your mighty acts?
tn.text: The writer uses a question to express deep emotion and concern because it seems God is not helping them. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "We do not see your zeal and your mighty acts!" (See: UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Your pity and your compassionate actions are kept from us
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "You keep your pity and compassion from us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: though Abraham does not know us, and Israel does not recognize us
tn.text: These ancestors of the nation of Israel would not able to identify their descendants because they changed so much. "Abraham" and "Israel" represent the distant past. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The people of Israel continue speaking.

tn.ref: Yahweh, why do you make us wander from your ways and harden our hearts, so we do not obey you?
tn.text: Here the writer uses a question to express a complaint of the people to God. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Yahweh, you have made us wander from your ways and become stubborn so that we do not obey you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: why do you make us wander from your ways
tn.text: To not do what Yahweh commands is spoken of as if a person wanders off of the correct path. AT: "why do you make do what is wrong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This means to become resistant to Yahweh's teaching by refusing to listen and obey. Here "heart" represents their motives, feelings and desires. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The people of Israel continue speaking.

tn.ref: who were never called by your name
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. "name" refers to a family relationship. AT: "who never belonged to your family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: We have become ... called by your name
tn.text: Some modern versions interpret this passage differently: "We are like the people over whom you have not ruled, like those who have not been called by your name."
